summary: the bis-benzylisoquinoline alkaloids tetrandrine (TET), fangchinoline (FAN), and cepharanthine (CEP) are the major sources of the bis-benzylisoquinoline alkaloids tetrandrine (TET), fangchinoline (FAN), and cepharanthine (CEP) these herbal plants have been traditionally used for various medicinal purposes in the east Asian countries. human coronavirus strains OC43 (HCoV-OC43; -CoV) and 229E (-CoV) have been considered as mostly responsible for the common cold [17,18] HCoV-OC43 is responsible for up to 30% of respiratory infections and can cause repeated reinfections throughout life. HCoV-OC43 shares several functional properties with both [22,23]. bChem CID: 73481) and CEP were purchased from Wuhan ChemFaces Biochemical Co., Ltd. (Wuhan, China) each compound was freshly prepared to the indicated concentrations with fetal bovine serum (FBS)-free culture medium before use. the concentration of dimethyl sulfoxide in this experiment did not exceed 0.05%. cytopathic effect of the infected cells was quantified by crystal violet staining. serial 10-fold dilutions of the HCoV-OC43 stocks (101 to 108) were prepared in MEM. MRC-5 cells (1 104) were seeded in the wells of 96-well tissue culture plates. the next day, the cells were infected with HCoV-OC43. the compounds were added to the MRC-5 cells either during (co-treatment) or 24 h after infection (post-treatment) RNA transcripts were obtained using the InvitrogenTM MEGAscriptTM T7 Transcription Kit. purification of viral RNA in the filtered culture supernatants was performed using a commercial viral RNA purification kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany) total RNA was synthesized to complementary DNA using the RNeasy® mini kit. the sequences of the human-specific primers used for qRT-PCR are listed in Table 1. a 20-g aliquot of the extracted protein was separated by 8% sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. the membranes were blocked by incubation with 5% skim milk for 1 h at room temperature. after washing three times with TBST, the membranes were incubated with primary antibodies against the HCoV-OC43 spike glycoprotein (Cusabio Technology LLC, Houston, TX, USA) MRC-5 cells were fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde and washed with ice-cold PBS. the fixed cells were permeabilized with PBS containing 0.2% Triton X-100. the cells were incubated with a monoclonal primary antibody against the HCoV-OC43 N protein. each compound was freshly prepared to the indicated concentrations with fetal bovine serum (FBS)-free culture medium before use. the concentration of dimethyl sulfoxide in this experiment did not exceed 0.05%. MRC-5 cells reached 90% confluence in MEM supplemented with 2% heat-inactivated FBS, 100 U/mL of penicillin, and 100 g/mL of streptomycin at 33 °C under a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2. when the cells reached 50% confluence, the supernatant was harvested and filtered with a 0.22-m Stericup® Filter Unit (EMD Millipore Corporation, Billerica, MA, USA time-of-Addition Assay MRC-5 cells (1 104) were seeded in the wells of 96-well tissue culture plates. after 24 h, the compounds were removed by washing. the next day, the cells were infected with HCoV-OC43 for four days. the optical density of each well was measured at a wavelength of 490 nm. the sequence of the HCoV-OC43 nucleoprotein (N protein; 138 bp) coded by the pBIC-A vector (DNA concentration, 1 g) was linearized with the XhoI restriction enzyme and purified with the HiYield PlusTM Plasmid Mini Kit (Real Biotech Corporation, Banqiao City, Taiwan) qRT-PCR MRC-5 cells (1 105) were seeded in the wells of 24-well tissue culture plates. the next day, the cells were infected with HCoV-OC43. each compound (5 M) was added to the wells. a 20-g aliquot of the extracted protein was separated by 8% sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. after washing three times with TBST, the membranes were incubated with primary antibodies against the HCoV-OC43 spike glycoprotein (cusabio Technology LLC, Houston, TX, USA) d Array (CBA) of inflammatory cytokines was performed using a BDTM CBA Human Inflammatory Cytokines Kit (BD Biosciences, San Jose, CA, USA) data were analyzed using a BDTM CBA Human Inflammatory Cytokines Kit (BD Biosciences, San Jose, CA, USA) Statistical analysis was performed using GraphPad Prism Software V.6.05 for Windows (GraphPad Software, Inc., San Diego, CA, USA) data are presented as mean standard error of the mean (SEM) Probability (p) values were calculated by one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Tukey’s test as indicated in the figure legends. no cytotoxicity was caused by the compounds within the effective ranges, even at a concentration as high as 10 M (CC50 > 10 M) the IC50 values of TET, FAN, and CEP were 295.6, 919.2, and 729.7 nM, respectively, which resulted in selectivity indices of > 40, 11, and 13, respectively. MRC-5 cells were treated with 0.2, 1, and 5 M of the compounds at 24 h before infection with HCoV-OC43 (pre-treatment) compound administration at 24 h after treatment significantly increased MRC-5 cell survival in a dose-dependent manner at a rate comparable to that of the co-treatment group. the compounds were added at 24 h before, during, or 24 h after HCoV-OC43 infection of MRC-5 cells. cell viability of pre, co-, post- compound treated cells was assessed using the MTS assay at four dpi. MRC-5 cells were treated with 5 M compounds (Vehicle 0.025% DMSO) for 24 h (pre 24), 12 h (pre 12), 6 h (pre 6), and 3 h (pre 3) prior to HCoV-OC43 infection or during infection (co 0–96), at 12 h (post 12–96), 24 h (post 24–96), and 48 h (post 48–96) post-infection. virus infection promoted cell death and increased the release of HCoV-OC43 into the supernatant. however, treatment with TET, FAN, and CEP significantly inhibited virus-induced cell death and the release of the virus into the supernatant. however, compound treatment significantly decreased the copy number of viral RNA in cell lysates in the vehicle group. HCoV-OC43 copy number, nucleoprotein (N) and spike glycoprotein (S) protein expression, and sialic acid acetylesterase (SIAE) mRNA levels in MRC-5 cells were inhibited. images were captured by fluorescence microscopy at two dpi. HCoV-OC43 infection induced the expression of IFN-related antiviral genes in MRC-5 cell lysates at 1, 2, 3, and 4 dpi. mxA mRNA expression was increased by compound treatment at one dpi compared with virus-infected MRC-5 cells without compound treatment. mRNA levels of (A) IFN-1, (B) IFN-1, (C) IFN-1, and (D) MxA genes were measured by qRT-PCR in vehicle (0.025% DMSO), TET-, FAN-, and CEP-treated cell lysates. the kinetics of various inflammatory cytokines were evaluated at four dpi. MRC-5 cells with or without HCoV-OC43 infection were treated with vehicle (0.025% DMSO), or the compounds (5 M) the secretion of inflammatory cytokines IL-1, IL-6, and IL-8 was quantified by CBA in the compound-treated virus-uninfected supernatant (A) and the compound-treated virus-infected supernatant (B) at 1, 3, and 4 dpi. the viability of HCoV-OC43-infected MRC-5 cells was similar to 100 nM ANM + 0.3 M TET versus 100 nM ANM. however, there was no synergistic effect of TET and ANM against HCoV-OC43. cytopathic effects of HCoV-OC43 in MRC-5 cells were determined using the MTS assay. the 50% cytotoxic concentration (CC50) values of the compounds were 14.51, 12.40, and 10.54 M, respectively. MRC-5 cells were cultured with two-fold serial dilutions of each compound (from 10 M) MRC-5 cells were cultured from 20 M for four days. cell viability was assessed using the 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-5-(3-carboxymethoxyphenyl)-2-(4-sulfophenyl)-2H-tetrazolium assay. MRC-5 cells were treated with 0.2, 1 and 5 M of the compounds at 24 h before infection with HCoV-OC43 (pre-treatment) compound administration at 24 h after treatment significantly increased MRC-5 cell survival in a dose-dependent manner at a rate comparable to that of the co-treatment group. MRC-5 cells were treated with 5 M compounds at 24, 12, 6, and 3 h before HCoV-OC43 infection, during infection, and at 12, 24, and 48 h post-infection. the viability of cells treated with the compounds at 48 h after infection was similar to that of the untreated group. MRC-5 cells were infected with HCoV-OC43, and the compounds (5 M) were added. the supernatants and cell lysates were harvested at 1, 2, 3, and 4 dpi. compound treatment significantly inhibited virus-induced cell death. mRNA levels of sialic acid acetylesterase were dramatically induced by HCoV-OC43 infection in MRC-5 cells at four dpi. mRNA levels of sialic acid acetylesterase were dramatically induced by HCoV-OC43 infection in MRC-5 cells at four dpi. oV-OC43-infected MRC-5 cells were treated with 5 M TET, FAN, and CEP (Vehicle 0.025% DMSO) the culture supernatant and cell lysates were harvested at designated times. cell viability was assessed using the MTS assay at 1, 2, 3, and 4 days post-infection (B and C) HCoV-OC43 infection induced the expression of IFN-related antiviral genes in MRC-5 cell lysates at 1, 2, 3, and 4 dpi. mxA mRNA expression was increased by compound treatment at one dpi compared with virus-infected MRC-5 cells without compound treatment. mxA levels following compound treatment were lower than those of the vehicle control. TNF, IL-1, IL-6, IL-8, and IL-12p70 were not detected in the MRC-5 cell culture supernatant following compound treatment. however, treatment with the compounds did not induce MRC-5 to produce the inflammatory cytokines IL-1, IL-6, and IL-8. TET promoted the P38 Phosphorylation of MAPK in HCoV-OC43-infected MRC-5 cells. p38 phosphorylation peaked at 30 min post-infection and then slowly decreased at 60 and 90 min. p38 MAPK signaling pathway is activated by TET in MRC-5 cells. increased phosphorylation of p38 MAPK by TET treatment in MRC-5 cells with no antiviral synergistic effect of TET and anisomycin. p38 phosphorylation of p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) was infected with HCoV-OC43. the genome of HCoV-OC43 encodes some well-conserved motifs shared with SARS-CoV. this suggests that HCoV-OC43 could be an alternative model for the study of emerging HCoVs. the results of the present study demonstrated that TET, FAN, and CEP are potentially strong natural antiviral agents for the treatment of HCoV infection. pretreatment with the compounds increased cell survival rates against virus infection. pretreatment with the compounds increased cell survival rates against virus infection. of particular interest, only 3 h of pre-exposure to TET and FAN fully protected against virus-induced cell death. HCoV-OC43 infection induced a significant increase in the mRNA level of SIAE in MRC-5 cells at four dpi as a virus-induced host response. however, SIAE mRNA levels were lowered by treatment with TET, FAN, and CEP. IL-1, IL-6, and IL-8 levels were increased in MRC-5 cells by HCoV-OC43 infection. the production of inflammatory cytokines was not affected by the compound treatment dose. a recent study reported that TET activates the MAPK signaling pathway. TET, FAN, and CEP significantly inhibited virus-induced cell death with no apparent cytotoxicity at the effective doses. treatment with TET, FAN, and CEP dramatically suppressed the replication of HCoV-OC43 in the supernatants and lysates of MRC-5 cells.
